1112779767588286466.text:
8/ 

I asked if I could take a photo of us.  She hugged me tight like an old friend while we smiled at my iPhone.

Two human beings side by side.  The first spring night in New York City after a brutal winter.

1112779766875279360.text:
7/ 

We even spoke about what she likes to drink - Orange juice.

1112779766053076992.text:
6/ 

She asked me questions about my life.  We spoke about her cigarette habit, how she’s trying to quit.  Staring at the Pizzeria across the street, I asked if she’d had dinner.  Yes, macaroni and cheese that someone’d given her.

1112779764387987457.text:
5/ 

She told me that she’d just been to Atlanta to see her grandmother.  

“No wonder you’re so nice,” I said.  “You’re Southern.”

To that, she smiled.

1112779762601287682.text:
4/ 

“Can I join you?” I asked.

“Sure.”  She scooted aside, giving me room.  

We sat and watched New Yorkers pass by. 

“Where do you live?” I asked.

“Used to on the streets,” she said.  “These days, I stay by Lexington and 23rd.”

1112779761800052737.text:
3/ 

“Laying low,” I said.

“How’ve you been?”

I’d been going through something.  I told her the 1.5 sentence version.  She smiled quietly and gave me a hug.  It felt honest and real.  Then, she sat down.

1112779760109748224.text:
2/ 

“My friend,” she stood and shouted as I walked up the block.  Then, when I got close, “Where’ve you been?”

Last time I saw her was sometime in mid-December.  We only knew each other in passing, when I’d occasionally drop money in her cup, reminding her to stay warm.

1095789856729513984.text: 19/ Tonight, if you hug the one you love, do it just a little tighter.  Just a little longer.  Like it’s the last time you might ever get to.  Because one day, it will be.

1095789855500627969.text: 18/ As I warned you, this isn’t a feel good piece.  Just an honest one.

1095789854229704715.text: 17/ So, a woman is dead.  Already, less than two weeks later, maybe 2,000 who lived nearby have joined the ranks.  Some by choice, most not.  Given the density of Manhattan, some only blocks from where she lived.  Tomorrow, more.  And the next day.  And the next day.

1095789852933742592.text: 16/ But averages exist in statistics, not life.  In reality, one day it could be 200, next day 135, and so on.  Out of those, every other day, one is struck by a subway train.  Life only gives you facts.  Cold and hard when they get personal.

1095789851713175553.text: 15/ Over 54,000 people die in New York City each year.  If you average it out, that’s 150 people a day.  Gone from the lives of those who love them forever.

1095789850425462785.text: 14/ The hardest part is that after a while, your memories become wisps.  You start to forget what they smelled like.  The sound of that particular ring in their laugh.  The way their skin felt.  The way they looked at you.  What’s left behind is shadows.  And sometimes, regrets.

1095789849234362368.text: 13/ Everything is reversible in life.  Everything.  Except death.

1095789847967657987.text: 12/ The human body is an amazing marvel.  And yet, when you drill down to the biochemistry, it’s insane how the whole thing functions without falling apart.  Well, it often does.  ER docs could bore you to death on all the ways a healthy seeming person can drop.

1095789846226972682.text: 11/ Or, just a good old fashioned heart attack.

1095789844566028289.text: 10/ Straight out of college, I worked in a busy ER.  You name it, I saw it.  Some, self-inflicted.  Most, the reality of life.  He was crossing the street like any other day and got sideswiped by a car and next thing you know, he’s coding in the ambulance.

1095789843307728896.text: 9/ And that’s that.  There’s no use arguing her decision.  Only choice left is to understand.  The thing is, life is fragile, and so are we.  Even the strongest have cracks within.  And to go through life numb is one of the hardest things there is.

1095789842078879745.text:
8/ “It’s not exactly easy for me either,” she said, wrapping it up.  “I’m here for you.  I love you.  I always have and I always will, I promise.”

She used the Japanese words, Shikata ga’nai.  Meaning, nothing can be done about it.

Finally, “I’m really sorry mama.”

1095789840359141405.text:
7/ There was no feeling sorry for herself.  Just matter of fact and giving, if you can call it that.  This is not your fault, she said.  She asked you to have one delicious meal in her honor.  

In her words: “I mean a really really great meal.”

1095789839088316416.text: 6/ She felt absolutely nothing, she said.  Then she listed the things she would miss.  She listed all sorts of food, hugs, saying “I love you.”  She listed tracing a sleeping eyebrow.

1095789837460881408.text: 5/ “I realize I am undeserving of thinking this way because I truly have a great life on paper….It’s the ultimate first world problem, I get it.”

1095789836190003202.text:
4/ The note was honest, it was real, and it showed her personality.  She titled it: “I hate the word ‘bye,’ but see you later maybe?”

She was plain old-fashioned tired of feeling tired, she said.

1095789834948493312.text: 3/ She lived in the West Village on W 10th.  They found her with a cloth around her neck after she posted a note on her site.  A news outlet pointed out that she was pretty.  As if one’s outside is any reflection of what’s inside.

1095789833740578816.text: 2/ I stared at it for a while.  Every link you follow on the web is a journey into your own mind.  Then, I clicked through.

5/ For anything you create, ask yourself two questions.

- Who is this for?
- Did I give it my very best?

Be brutally honest in your answers.

If you want to create anything lasting, this is a must.

1076482651664642053.text: 4/ So, in this case, however many drafts it takes for you to honestly say, “I gave it my very best.”

1076482650402107395.text: 3/ Editors are not miracle workers.  Give them the very best thing you could create.  Not what you vomited all over a page.

1076482649278111744.text:
2/ My answer: depends on who you’re writing for.

If for yourself, then it’s a journal.  Put it out and be done with it. 

If for the reader, then it’s your responsibility to craft it with great care.

1017060657156509696.text: 14/ Here’s to the greats.  To what we may learn from them - from their work, their lives...and their mistakes.

1017060655411744775.text: 13/ After all, to create anything pure and true is a joy in itself.  They robbed themselves of that too.

1017060653658509313.text: 12/ And that applies to @Bourdain, to all those who go before their time.  What else could they have created that would have brought us joy?  What would they have taught us?

1017060652802768896.text: 11/ What else could he have created?

1017060651070574592.text: 10/ When I read his biography, even though I knew what was coming, I cried when I read the moment he killed himself.  I cried selfishly.  What else could he have written if he’d stuck around?

1017060649350975488.text: 9/ Hemingway led to other writers to study.  But he was the first.  He was the master who showed me the power of craft.  And dedication to it.

1017060647614533639.text: 8/ With commas.  Even just what he did with commas.

1017060646343585793.text: 7/ I grew obsessed with Hemingway, studied his works, line by line.  When friends were out partying, I was at home, trying to figure out how he did what he did with sentences.

1017060645362196480.text: 6/ Showed me what an amateur I was as a writer.  But, it also showed me what was possible with the written word.

1017060643520819200.text: 5/ When I first finished “For Whom the Bell Tolls,” I couldn’t believe that a human being had written that.  It blew my mind.

1017060642493206529.text: 4/ Read their lives.  And, in my case, if their art is the same as yours, then by God, that is as good as it gets.

1017060641654308865.text: 3/ I hear people asking for mentors.  The best mentors are available to us for next to nothing!  Their work is the teaching.

1017060639930572801.text: 2/ It was Hemingway who showed me what real writing was.  How far I had to go as a writer.  The courage that it took to write what was real and true.

1017060633446113281.text: 1/ One of the best gifts I’ve ever received.  First edition, “For Whom the Bell Tolls” by Ernest Hemingway.pic.twitter.com/VlG0DbBbK9

I wrote this for you.

999720691300798464.text:
23/ Want to educate yourself on expanders? 

Listen to these podcasts by @tferriss
https://tim.blog/2018/02/20/gabor-mate/ …
https://tim.blog/2015/09/14/are-psychedelic-drugs-the-next-medical-breakthrough/ …

999720689568448512.text:
22/ And there is a world of healing available that they may not touch because it gets lumped in with the system’s definition of drugs.

I owe it to them to share this.

999720687836319744.text:
21/ So…why these tweets?

Honestly, I’m scared of putting this out there.  I will be judged.  

But a follow-up conversation with my friend reminded me that there are those who do need help.  Who do not have the benefit of the life that he does.

999720686150209538.text:
20/ Returning to my friend.  Did he lick the toad?

Nope.

But he listened to my definition of what contracts and what expands and I’m grateful for his open-mindedness.  I respect anyone who stays true to their path.

999720683604271105.text:
19/ You might choose a different path, this was just a fork in the road I’ve explored.  We all have our own GPS.  Our job is to follow it.

And yes, I am better for it.

999720681968414720.text:
18/ Wait a minute, you might say.  The dude who wrote Love Yourself has done these expanders?  

Yup.

But loving himself transformed his life.

All true.

Then why do these?

Because when you love yourself, you’ll do everything you believe will make you better.

999720680710078469.text:
17/ Most of the people involved in the system are good.  They believe they’re doing the right thing.  I respect them for that. 

It’s easier to blame than to fix.  

Let’s focus on fixing this so those who need expanders will have access to them.

999720677556084736.text:
16/ It would be easy to blame the system.  After all, the drug war is one of the greatest tragedies of our time.  And big Pharma is structured to create and push molecules they can patent.

But it’s not that simple.

999720675840577540.text:
15/ In our system, we prescribe painkillers and make addicts out of those who’re already suffering.

Yet, every expander I’ve mentioned is considered illegal.

There is profit in addiction.  There is no profit in healing.

999720674095763456.text:
14/ Brave doctors and practitioners are using iboga, ahyuasca, toad, mushrooms to treat addiction and severe ptsd.  The results, I hear, are night and day.

Yet, most have to do this in hiding.

999720672380190720.text:
13/ Actual studies with addicts show them clean from addiction after three days of iboga.

Three.  Days. 

No withdrawal. 

And it lasts.

I repeat.  Heroin addicts.  Free from addiction.  After three days.  No withdrawal symptoms. 

Beat that, pharma.

999720670706720769.text:
12/ Iboga (also Ibogaine).  It’s a root bark from Africa.  Done properly, you’re basically in a semi-coma for a couple days.  Your entire life plays out before you.  
You get to experience the consequences of your choices.  The affect they’ve had on others.

Not easy.

999720669087764480.text:
11/ You know what they call these in the cultures they come from?

Medicine.  Teachers.  Healers.  Grandfathers.  Grandmothers.

They expand your Spirit.

999720668005617664.text:
10/ The most important part....

There are things we call drugs that have no business in that camp.  

They save lives.  Literally.

Ahyuasca, Iboga, peyote, mushrooms, the above-mentioned toad...

999720667237974016.text:
9/ Cocaine is the stupidest drug.  Want a guaranteed way to make choices you’ll regret?  Sign right up.

Alcohol, painkillers.  A chunk of what is prescribed legally.  Drugs, all.

Drugs destroy lives.

But....

999720665476423680.text:
8/ Meth, for example.  It was where I met the devil.  And he was more powerful than me.

When you’re on meth, you don’t give a f**k.  About anything.  Including yourself.  Especially yourself.  

You’d walk in front of a truck and not care.

But for the grace of God, here am I.

999720663786106880.text:
7/ So I went for the “easy” route.  The escape route.

Here’s what I know about drugs.  

There are things we call drugs that are drugs.  They contract your Spirit.  

They destroy you.

999720662074904576.text:
6/ Here is what I told him:

In fact, lemme bare it all.  So you understand that I speak from experience.

I’ve known drugs.  And they’ve known me.

At a point in my life, I was on a mission to destroy myself.  But I was too much of a coward to face it directly.

999720660338397185.text:
5/ My friend was on the fence.  According to him, it could be perfect for his personal struggles.  

He’d seen the effect it’d had on friends.  All for the better.

“But it’s a drug,” he said.  “I don’t want to do drugs.”

He asked me if he should do it.

999720658610335745.text:
4/ Want to experience your death?  Want to fully let go to what is?  This is it.  Die before you die so you can be reborn.

Either way, it’s one heck of a ride.

999720656932605952.text:
3/ Your brain releases it on its own when you’re dying.  That light at the end of the tunnel?  Hello, DMT.  If you’re secular, that’s simple enough.

If you believe in more, then perhaps it’s your brain releasing you to the other side.

999720655217135616.text:
2/ The actual mechanism is well-known.  You don’t lick the toad anymore.  

Instead, you smoke the resin.  It’s a form of DMT.  Some call it, the Spirit Molecule.

999720653036179457.text:
1/ While back, a friend had a chance to lick a toad that would make him see God.  He’s never drank or smoked anything in his life.  

The experience he’d been offered was thousands of years old.  Practiced by indigenous tribes.  Everyone I know who’d done it was better for it.

997867012239101953.text:
4/ Now, my twitter experience is intentional.  I open my app and all I see is dog petting goodness.

Then, I go to whatever list I wish to learn from.  

And life on twitterverse is good...

997867010594885634.text:
3/ The only account I follow is @IvePetThatDog.

A 9 year-old boy named Gideon who pets a different dog every day.

997867009525338112.text:
2/ I unfollowed everyone.  

Instead, I’m creating lists.  Everyone I used to follow or will follow goes into the appropriate one (family, friends, writing, venture capital, health, fitness, funny...).

997867008359268352.text:
1/ My Twitter feed’s been a zoo.  I’ve noticed that each time I’m on Twitter, my state of mind is less calm.  Yet, I love Twitter.  So many amazing people to learn from.

So, this is what I did...
